settings.blog-title: HOW TO STORE YOUR CLOTHES PROPERLY

settings.text: At Chinti & Parker, we firmly believe that clothes are made to be enjoyed. To ensure your favourite styles can be worn for as long as possible, they require dedicated care and attention. Whether between seasons or between wears, here is our expert advice for preserving and prolonging your garments for as long as possible.

settings.grid-content:
Launder like a pro

Before storing your clothes, ensure they are freshly laundered. Food and drink debris can attract moths and insects, even when the clothes aren’t visibly stained. Always follow the washing and drying instructions exactly, then iron - if necessary - and fold carefully before putting away.

Take note of items that require specialist care. Often, this is simply a case of heading to your local dry cleaner before packing those treasured pieces away.

To fold or to hang?

Know which items belong in your wardrobe and which in your drawers. Trousers should be hung, folded over carefully to avoid wrinkling and creases. Hang your coats and outerwear, along with shirts, blouses and dresses. Avoid “doubling up” on hangers.

Sweaters and cardigans should be folded, with cashmere and other delicate fabrics to be kept in a drawer or storage box. If you’re storing these for a prolonged period, such as between seasons, ensure they are freshly laundered and free of dirt, hair and sweat. Short-sleeve T-shirts can be folded, whereas you may choose to hang long-sleeved ones.

How were you introduced to Chinti & Parker and why is the brand such a good fit for Women for Women International?

We’ve been working with Chinti & Parker since 2018, when the brand launched a collection in aid of Women for Women International. I love the fact that the brand is the brainchild of two women, Anna and Rachael, who have an inherent understanding of what women want to feel and look good in. This is so reflective of the women who go through our programme. Many of them become successful entrepreneurs or work together in embroidery / craft cooperatives.

settings.grid-content:
Ditch the wire hangers

Speaking of hanging, it’s time to ditch the wire hangers. As heavier items weigh them down, they will bend, leaving dents or distortions in your clothes. Replace them with high-quality wooden hangers. These hold your clothes better, can support heavier items, and will last much longer, too.

Invest in garment bags for your most delicate or special pieces. Choose bags made from a breathable material, and if you wrap the items in paper, opt for acid-free tissue paper to avoid damage.

Deter moths and insects

Moths can spell disaster for your delicate knits, especially that precious cashmere. Cedar and lavender are natural deterrents, and a great alternative to mothballs. Use lavender sachets or cedar balls but avoid direct contact with your garments, as they can spread oils. Find out more about taking care of your cashmere here.

Those special pieces

Heavy items, such as wool jackets, and beaded or embellished gowns should be laid flat. Hanging pieces like these can put stress on the shoulder seams and lead to the fabric stretching over time. For these items, choose acid-free garment boxes, and store well away from direct sunlight in a location where you can control the temperature, humidity and keep it free from pests.

Maximise your space 

If you struggle with wardrobe space, you may consider rotating your clothing according to the season. Read how to create a winter capsule wardrobe to get started. Begin by organising your clothes into categories, as this will make it much easier to unpack everything when the time comes. Store in specialist boxes and avoid vacuum packing at all costs. Although this may seem like a space-saver, it can leave indentations and put pressure on buttons, zips and seams.
